speech: O'Neill tries to back away, but the device grabs his head. A bright light shines.
Hammond, Fraiser, Teal'c and others watch in wonder as O'Neill types at a terminal.
Later, several Stargate locations show on a screen. Carter now sits at the station.
The colonel must have input new Stargate locations into the computer.
Teal'c is restrained. Ba'al stands nearby.
(in Goa'uld echo) Jaffa number in the millions spread across the vastness of the galaxy...what you need right now is a strong leader.
While Daniel attempts to dial the DHD, both the Stargate and DHD disappear as if beamed away by Asgard beaming technology. Daniel stares, mouth agape.
SG-1, studying reports, and Emerson sit around the table.
He's been gathering up Stargates from all over the sector for the last several weeks.
Teal'c and Daniel sit at a table.
In Arthurian myth, Morgan was a powerful sorceress, King Arthur's half-sister and an adversary of Merlin.
That would suggest she may have had a hand in the disappearance of the weapon we seek.
Daniel and Vala use the database.
We're looking for the names of two planets, known on Earth in ancient times in the dialect of Old English as Castiana and Sahal.
You're not really a hologram, are you?
(looking directly at Daniel) You have your answer, Daniel Jackson. I suggest you act on it.
Landry, Vala, and SG-1, sans Daniel, sit around the table. Vala is turned away from the others, looking bored.
What's the latest from the search parties?
The toxic atmosphere on Castiana is slowing us down considerably. Now we found evidence of stone structures on Sahal, but they appear to have been abandoned over 40,000 years ago.
You went all the way to the Pegasus galaxy, you had a face-to-face encounter with a full-blown Ascended Being, came away with not one, but two gate addresses, and they both turn out to be dead ends?
Well, see, that's the part that doesn't make any sense, sir. If Morgan didn't want us to find Merlin's weapon, then why tell us anything at all? We must be missing something.
That's what Dr. Jackson keeps telling me.
Vala spins around with sudden interest.
Mitchell glowers at Vala, but Vala merely smiles at him and shrugs it off.
He checked in from Camelot this morning. He's convinced that the answer is somewhere in Merlin's library, but he hasn't found anything yet.
(over intercom) Sorry to interrupt, General. You're needed in the control room.
Landry groans and stands. He and the others leave the room.
All of them come down the staircase from the briefing room and approach Harriman's station.
We just received a heads-up from NORAD, sir. An Al'kesh bomber just entered Earth's atmosphere about four minutes ago. Bearing indicates Cheyenne Mountain.
(after listening to his earpiece) Two F-16s out of Peterson have been rerouted to intercept. I'm patching us in.
(over radio) Repeat, you have entered a flight restricted zone and are requested to land immediately. Please respond.
The Al'kesh continues to descend, the two F-16s following.
(over radio) Stargate Command, this is Bearcat One. The alien vessel is unresponsive. Should we engage?
If they were friendly, they wouldn't be flying silent.
We can't take the chance. (louder) Bearcat One, this is General Landry. You are cleared to engage.
An F-16 launches a missile, which strikes the port engine exhausts and explodes. The Al'kesh falters.
Everyone waits tensely for further word.
(over radio) The alien vessel has been disabled. They're coming down hard.
The team leave the control room.

An unmarked SUV drives along a rural road and stops. Several vehicles are parked nearby, including a military ambulance. The crashed Al'kesh sits in the field. Mitchell, Carter, Teal'c and Vala exit the SUV. Major Caffey greets the team.
The area has been secured. No one on board except for the pilot. He's being treated for minor injuries.
Let's have a look at him.
Caffey leads them around the ambulance vehicle. The doors are wide open. A medic moves from where he is treating the pilot's head injury. The pilot is Ba'al, still holding some gauze to his forehead.
Ah, at last. The welcoming committee.
The team shares shocked and suspicious looks with each other.
Carter works at a station. Mitchell, Teal'c and Vala watch a monitor showing Ba'al pacing in an interrogation room, furnished with only a table and chairs.
I don't get it. We know that Ba'al has come to Earth before without being detected.
Presumably by cloaked cargo ship or by using Asgard beaming technology from high orbit.
Exactly. So why would he fly an Al'kesh directly to Stargate Command?
Maybe he was planning to attack?
Nah, even Ba'al's not that crazy.
Well, this is interesting. There's a signal coming from inside the interrogation room. He must have implanted himself with a locator beacon.
No doubt, he's expecting his people to beam him out at some point.
Well, after the Stargate was stolen two years ago, we installed jamming devices to prevent anyone from locking onto a signal from within the base.
While Carter speaks, Landry enters the lab from behind her.
Only that he won't talk to anybody but SG-1.
Frankly, I'm inclined to let him rot.
That's all right, sir. We'll...we'll talk to him. After all, he did come all this way.
The door opens, and the team enter the cell. Ba'al notes each of them.
Colonel Mitchell. Colonel Carter. Teal'c. Qetesh.
Ba'al smugly takes a seat. Carter sits across from him.
Vala and Carter exchange knowing looks. Teal'c pointedly stands facing away from Ba'al, though able to watch him peripherally. Mitchell crosses his arms.
We've been authorized to give you the time of day, so make it quick and make it good.
Of course. I understand your reluctance to trust me, so I'll be succinct. It's the clones. They want me dead.
That would make all of us.
Dead, huh? What'd you do? Short-sheet the bed? Cheat at cards?
You must understand that what I did was out of necessity. You were the ones who invited the Ori into this galaxy. I was merely trying to preserve a safe haven for myself and a few...good friends.
Vala leans forward, both hands braced against the table, studying Ba'al.
So you stole a few Stargates, tried to set up your own network. Yadda, yadda, yadda. We were there, remember?
Luckily, I wasn't. I had to hear about your heroics thirdhand. I also had to hear about how you thwarted my attempts to gain control of the Jaffa High Council.
But none of this explains why the clones would turn on you.
That's probably because there's a little more to his plan than he's letting on.
Ba'al nods at Vala with a hint of respect. Vala crouches down next to Carter who turns to her.
(low to Carter) Didn't Daniel tell me something about a very powerful weapon in the hands of the Jaffa on Dakara?
It's not a weapon, technically. It was a device that was originally used by the Ancients to seed all life in this galaxy, but we did adapt it to destroy the Replicators.
(leaning forward and stretching out his arms) Using my simultaneous dialing program, I might add.
Carter flashes a humorless smile and turns back to Vala.
Am I correct in assuming that this device can be adapted to kill organic life as well?
(rising) Now it's starting to make sense.
Ba'al clasps his hands and lifts them so they hide his mouth's expression, but his eyes sparkle with interest.
Well, you must remember that I have intimate knowledge of just how depraved the Goa'uld can be.
You are suggesting that Ba'al attempted to gain control of the High Council in order to gain access to the Ancient device.
With the purpose of wiping out all life in the galaxy, except his own little corner, of course.
Ba'al lowers his hands and looks at Vala with a defiant smile.
(chuckling) I never said it was original. But if I had succeeded, the Ori would've lost interest and been on their merry way.
You were going to save the galaxy by destroying pretty much everyone in it?
But your clones figured out you weren't bring them along, didn't they?
They served their purpose. But what can I say? Their...egos were beginning to be a problem.
What I don't understand is, after this particular revelation, you thought SG-1 would want to help you.
Your search for Merlin's weapon, of course.
Teal'c faces Ba'al and the rest of his team looks equally interested.
Landry sits at his desk looking through papers. Harriman knocks at the open door, Barrett beside him.
Sir? Agent Barrett is here to see you.
Harriman motions for Barrett to enter, then departs. Barrett, carrying a briefcase enters.
Barrett. What can I do for you?
Barrett sets his briefcase down on Landry's desk.
I'm here for the prisoner, sir.
Ba'al. I have an official request for his transfer into NID custody.
Barrett opens his briefcase and pulls out a piece of paper, handing it to Landry.
You gotta be kidding. We caught him, we can handle it.

With all due respect, sir, it's my understanding he basically flew himself into your front door. Look, nobody wants a jurisdictional tug-of-war here. We've been investigating the Goa'uld infiltration of the Trust for two years now. I'm telling you, it's a global conspiracy. Political and corporate connections in over a dozen countries. Your prisoner is at the top of the pyramid.
We don't even know if he's the real Ba'al.
Even if he's a clone, I betcha he's got enough information to bring down the whole organization. We could wipe them out.
Eh, you're just gonna have to wait your turn. Right now, we've got bigger fish to fry.
Anubis told me of the weapon, and of its power. He dedicated considerable effort to finding it during his time in our plane of existence, but he never succeeded.
Actually, you have the address. It's among those Colonel O'Neill obtained during his encounter with the Ancient Repository of Knowledge, on the planet you call P3R-272.
There are thousands of addresses on that list.
Exactly why you'll never find it on your own. I, however, have information that will allow you to narrow down your choices considerably. All I ask in return is that you eliminate the clones.
And we do that exactly how?
It should be easy enough to track them down. I implanted a locator chip in each one when I created them.
That's funny, because we detected a locator chip in you.
I had to implant one in myself in order to gain their trust.
You can use the tracking system on board my Al'kesh. They'll never see it coming.
Well, that is a truly incredible story, in every sense of the word.

I should also mention that every one of my clones knows about Merlin's weapon, and if any one of them, at any point, were captured by the Priors, and were it to somehow...slip out...that the SGC computer contains the location of the weapon deadly to the Ori...
(interrupting) The Priors would stop at nothing to have it within their grasp.
It is of course, your decision. I leave it in your very "capable" hands.
Teal'c storms out, Vala, Carter, and Mitchell follow.
Landry and Barrett watch SG-1 leave the room.
You can't seriously think that he's telling the truth.
The whole truth? Of course not. But there's too much at stake here not to investigate.
And in the meantime, what am I supposed to tell my superiors?
Landry turns away and leaves, smiling to himself.
Landry, SG-1 and Vala sit around the table. Lee paces the room delivering a briefing.
We, uh, managed to activate the tracking system on the Al'kesh, and this is what we got.
Lee clicks a button on the remote in his hand and the screen shows dots indicating several different planet locations.
Landry and Teal'c each look unamused.
No one shares his amusement. Lee clears his throat and becomes serious again.
A-Any-anyway, we've worked up those files with the, uh, current locations showing the addresses and any available intel.
(leaning across to Carter) All right, so what kind of trap are we looking at?
I don't think it would be as simple as an ambush. Not while we have him in custody. No Goa'uld would sacrifice himself like that.
(turning to Landry) What do you think, sir?
Vala leans closer to Mitchell and rests her hand on the headrest of his chair.
(to Mitchell) I say we give it a go.
Remind me to give you a primer on the meaning of the word "sir". But she's right. We won't know if Ba'al is serious or not until we test out some of these addresses.
Carter looks down at the paper in front of her.
Some of this intel seems pretty sketchy.
Vala looks at Mitchell's copy of the report and points to part of the page.
I'm familiar with this planet. It used to belong to Camulus.
Mitchell and Carter exchange a look.
Landry and Mitchell step out of an elevator and start walking down the corridor.
You sure you want to bring her along on this one?
Jackson says she'll be useful. Now's her chance to prove it.
But Dr. Jackson isn't here, and it seems to me, he's the only one she ever listens to.
You don't think you can control her?

Oh, I know I can't control her. But that's pretty much par for the course. Sir...Carter and I are the same rank. Teal'c's an alien. Jackson's a civilian. I learned a long time ago, I don't "control" anything.
An airman hands Teal'c a P-90, which he receives with a nod. The airman then hands Mitchell his P-90. The two finish checking their gear.
Vala jogs into the armory, showing off her field BDUs and vest with excited flair. Carter follows at a more sedate pace.
Mitchell glances up briefly. Teal'c barely notice her, adjusting his weapon's belt.
Mitchell checks something on the back of her vest, then nods, turning back to his own preparations.
Vala spins back around with a content smile.
(to Teal'c) A little more enthusiasm from you next time.
The airman passes over a P-90. Vala takes it.
Mitchell immediately plucks it away and hands it over to Carter.
Carter follows Teal'c quickly away from Mitchell and Vala.
(incredulous) This is my first real mission through the gate, and I'm the only one who knows the terrain.
Try not to get us killed.
Mitchell walks away. The airman hands Vala a zat which she accepts with a grimace.
A ha'tak sits on the planet. Some distance away, SG-1 and Vala stand in a small clearing.
Vala kicks aside some brush with her foot, revealing a ring platform.
Well, it's a ring platform. Somewhat hidden, but it's a back door, if you will.
Okay, but it doesn't do us much good if we can't activate it.
She skips off into the trees.
(to Carter and Teal'c) Where's she going?
Carter shrugs and shakes her head.

Three Jaffa patrol the woods. Vala hides behind a large tree stump. Once they have passed, she casually moves around to the front of the stump and leans against it, zat in one hand. With her other, she puts two fingers to her mouth and whistles. The Jaffa spin around. She hits the first Jaffa with a zat blast then dives away before the others can aim properly. She runs through the woods dodging staff weapon blasts.
SG-1 hear weapons fire and crouch by cover, weapons ready. Vala jogs back out of the woods, a wide grin on her face.
What the hell are you doing?
I alerted a Jaffa patrol to our presence.
She stops in the middle of the platform, catching her breath.
Obviously. Do you mind if I ask why?
So they'd sound the alarm and send reinforcements.
(sarcastic) Oh, well that's...that's brilliant! Hey, how come I didn't think of that?
My dear Colonel, where do you think the reinforcements will come from?

Teal'c and Carter exchange looks. Vala glances at them, then looks at Mitchell with a grin and raised eyebrow as the other two scramble to stand beside her in the rings. After a glance to ensure no Jaffa are nearby, Mitchell joins them. Moments later, the rings activate. The four disappear, and four Jaffa appear in their place, moving off into the forest.
Four Jaffa march through the corridor. Mitchell, Carter, Vala, and Teal'c stay out of sight. Mitchell gives the all clear for them to move out two-by-two. Vala and Teal'c start out.
(as she passes) You can thank me later, by the way.
Mitchell and Carter exchange irritated looks before following.
The team moves down a corridor, pausing on either side of a doorway. Mitchell pulls out a smoke grenade, allowing Vala to pull the pin.
Several Jaffa stand guard around Ba'al Two, who sits on the throne. The grenade canister rolls to a stop by one Jaffa's foot. Ba'al Two notices it and stands up, alarmed.
The canister explodes, causing a flash and smoke to encompass the chamber. The team enters, Carter and Vala firing zats.
Ba'al Two reaches for a fallen staff weapon, but Teal'c steps on it, aiming his P-90 at the Goa'uld.
Don't shoot! I know why you're here, and you're making a big mistake.
He rises. Aside from Teal'c, Vala and Carter have their weapons aimed at him. Mitchell guards their rear.
Oh, let us guess. You're the real Ba'al.
No doubt the impostor promised you the location of Merlin's weapon if you helped him get rid of the rest of us.
You do realize he has no idea where it is, or how to find it.
Mitchell signals Vala to cover their line of retreat while he turns his attention to Ba'al. He unclips his P-90 and hands it to Carter.
Of course. I obtained the information only after the clones were created. And, needless to say, I never "shared" it with them.
Mitchell approaches, pulling out plastic restraints.
You know what? This is giving me a headache. What do you say, we finish this off at home? Let's go, Spartacus.
Mitchell ties Ba'al Two's hands behind his back and drags him off, Vala leading, the others following.

Both Ba'als are standing, talking to each other in the interrogation room. Both wear grey overalls, one labeled "one" and one labeled "two". The team and Landry observe the pair through the video monitor and the window.
(dryly) Oh yeah, now I can see the difference.
Do we really believe only one of them knows how to find the weapon?
This is Ba'al we're talking about. I don't think we can take anything either of them say at face value.
We've got scientists working here, don't we? Get 'em on this. See if they can sort out who's who.
Below them, the two Ba'als start to physically fight. SFs enter and zat the pair.
(dryly) In the meantime, I think I'm going to have to arrange for separate accommodations.
A geneticist and Carter review data on a computer screen.
I wish I had better news.
So you're saying there's no way to tell them apart?
We generated distinct DNA profiles of all four samples using a number of analysis techniques.
We did the host and the Goa'uld separately.

We ran each test five times, and each case the results were uncanny. It was a perfect match across all thirteen specific DNA markers. I'm sorry, Colonel. Either the clones are genetically indistinguishable from the real Ba'al...
...Or we have two clones on our hands, and the real Ba'al is still out there.
The team is in a firefight with several Jaffa.
So much for not encountering resistance.
I guess some Ba'als are bigger than others.
If he's got a ship back there, we're screwed. We've got to find another way around.
You hold this position. I'll go.
Carter stands and goes behind the others.
Vala and Carter run through the forest. Mitchell and Teal'c's weapons' fire are still audible in the distance. The two women stop and look at an open area.
(with knowing smile) Are you thinking what I'm thinking?
Vala nods and steps forward, picking up a rock and throwing it into the open area. It hits a force field. Vala smiles back at Carter.
Carter and Vala take cover. A Ba'al, wearing a long, earth-toned tunic, walks with several Jaffa guard.

Further in the forest, Mitchell and Teal'c fire at two last Jaffa. When no fire is returned, Mitchell moves forward to investigate. Over a small ridge, they see a wounded Ba'al wearing a black and gold outfit, lying amongst several dead Jaffa.
Don't shoot. I am the real Ba'al.
In the clearing, Carter stands calmly.
(into radio) Copy that. So do we.
She turns and looks to where Vala is covering the earth-toned style Ba'al with her zat.

Harriman waits at the bottom of the active Stargate with a clipboard in his hand. Mitchell and Carter walk through the gate first. Following are the two restrained Ba'als. Teal'c and Vala follow behind them.
Chief, we've got a full count. Two strikes, three Ba'als.
(rolling her eyes in amusement) He was thinking that one up the whole way home.
Behind them, guards escort the two prisoners out of the gate room, Vala and Teal'c follow.
Well, that ties you with SG-12, because they brought in two more about an hour ago.
Carter shakes her head and walks away.
He follows, Harriman pausing before also leaving.
Landry walks down a hall. Barrett approaches from another corridor.
Barrett. I was wondering when you'd be back.
(agitated) I understand you've got yourself a few extra Ba'als. I don't suppose you'd consider letting me take a few off your hands.
You know I can't do that. Not until we figure out which one's the original, and whether or not he's bluffing about Merlin's weapon.
The elevator door opens and both Landry and Barrett step inside. The doors close.
Besides, if any of them got wind that we had another agenda, it would give them leverage in the interrogation. The last thing we need is for them to think they have a strong bargaining position.
I was afraid you were going to say that.
I assume you spoke to your superiors.
The fact is, while the NID does provide civilian oversight of my command, I don't technically have to follow their orders...at least not until the President tells me to.
They tried that. For the moment, he is backing you. But if your investigation doesn't turn up anything useful soon, that's gonna all change.
The elevator doors open, and both exit.
I'd like to stay on and observe the interrogations. Any one of them could say something that might turn out to be useful.
Landry rounds the corner and enters the briefing room, where Mitchell, Carter, Vala and Teal'c are waiting, studying monitors filled with images of Ba'als. Barrett follows.
Well, sir, SG-14 just arrived with two more Ba'al clones, which brings us to the end of our list.
Well, you guys got your work cut out for you, huh?
The team stares, overwhelmed at all the Ba'als on the surveillance monitors. Several of the Goa'uld staring directly into the cameras.
A Ba'al sits across from Carter. An SF stands guard by the door.
And just how might you be able to help me?
Well, we could spare your life for one. You help us find Merlin's weapon, and I promise we won't kill you.
No. Instead, you'll lock me in the basement of one of your more appalling penal facilities--for me to live out the rest of my life in squalor and depravation.
It's better than the alternative. Trust me.

You see, here's what I'm thinking. I'm thinking that you're not the real Ba'al. I mean, you're haven't even tried to cut a deal, which makes me think that you have no idea how to find the weapon. Therefore, you're just another clone.
I am the real Ba'al, I assure you.
No, no, think about this. How did we meet? Do you think the real Ba'al would let himself be captured like that? Cowering in the bushes like a scared little bunny rabbit?
Ba'al's eyes flash with the Goa'uld glow.
That's better. But I'm still not buying it.
(leaning back) You're trying to goad me into revealing information.
No, I'm just calling it like I see it. And right now, you don't strike me as someone who could intimidate a ten year old out of his lunch money, much less run an interstellar empire.
(with echoing voice) Why don't you have the guard excuse himself for a moment, and I'll show you just what I am "capable" of?
(getting in his face) See now I know you're not the real Ba'al. The real Ba'al wouldn't care about the guard.
Ba'al One paces around a room. A tray of food sits on the table. An SF watches. The door opens and Vala enters. She nods to the guard a couple times, and with a final look at Ba'al One, he leaves.
So...having a tough day, are we?
Vala looks up at the surveillance cameras and saunters around the room. Ba'al One sits on the edge of the table.
Is that any way to greet an old friend?
I'll admit, we had our differences.
You attacked my fleet at Selenis, crippled my flagship, and killed 10,000 of my best Jaffa.
So I did. But it was nothing personal. Anyway, that's all in the past, and I'm here to talk about our future.
(slowly approaching him) You must admit there's always been something between us. Even when we wanted to kill each other, there was always certain...spark.
Vala gives Ba'al One a coquettish look.
Perhaps, but you've made your new allegiance clear.
Have I? (She looks up nervously at the camera and sighs.) Or have I just been waiting for the right opportunity?
You know how to find the address. I have access to the database.
(glancing at the camera) You would betray your Tau'ri friends?

Friends...come and go. Besides, what use are they going to be to me on their knees before the armies of the Ori? You tell me what you know. I'll find the location of Merlin's weapon. We'll make our escape. And then we'll be free to share in the pleasure of each other's company.
Vala gives him a confused look. Ba'al One turns to the table.
Merlin's weapon isn't going anywhere. We have nothing but time.
He shoves the tray of food off the table and knocks on it. He then grabs Vala by the arm and spins her against it.
(maintaining her smile) What? Here? On this rather...uncomfortable table?
Well, the security camera for starters. There's no way they'd trust me after seeing something like this.
She chuckles seductively. Both look up at the camera.
Tell them it was part of your interrogation technique.
(no longer smiling) Oh come on, be serious.
Vala shoves his hand away. He tries to put it back, but she strikes him. He grabs her by the throat.
(threatening) I am being serious. Aren't you?
He releases his grip and strokes one finger down her cheek.
Vala and Ba'al One appear in one of the monitors. Their dialogue is clearly audible. Ba'al moves around the table.
(over monitor) Your time amongst the Tau'ri is making you soft. You used to be a much better liar.
Landry and Barrett watch the monitor. Barrett is stifling laughter.
Your people are getting nowhere, sir.
Landry enters his office, Barrett follows.
You think you could do better?

It's what we're trained for. I could have half a dozen agents here by tomorrow. I'm talking about offering our services on your investigation. If any of the Ba'als knows where Merlin's weapon is, we'll find it.

By your own admission, the NID wants this over with as quickly as possible, so they can move onto something they think is more important. Under those circumstances, I think you'll understand why I'd prefer to stick with my own people.
Carter sits at a table and takes a sips from a mug. Barrett, holding a mug, comes up behind her.
(leaning over her shoulder) Mind if I join you?
So, how are the interrogations coming?
You have to ask? Look, I know you've been monitoring the investigation. I also know you think we're wasting our time.
No, no I never said that. Not in so many words.
Carter gives him a skeptical smile.

Look, you guys are fighting the war out there, right? We're fighting it down here. Believe me, it's a war. Do you remember two years ago when the Goa'uld almost took over the Russian government? Hmm? Do you want to see that happen again?
Malcolm, it's not like we're going to keep the Ba'als here forever. Just give us a couple of days, and then you can come in and...
(voice gradually rising) It's-no. This is way too important!
He slams his hand on the table, startling Carter and others in the room. He quickly composes himself.
This is about us, isn't it?
Yeah, this is about us. We obviously have unresolved issues.
(forcefully) Look, you're my friend, and I care about you, but don't push it.
Barrett gets up and walks away.
Barrett approaches the SF on duty.
I need to see the prisoner.
He whips out his credentials for the guard to see.

The guard glances at the badge, which Barrett flips closed. The guard takes his card key and swipes it. Barrett enters the room. The guard stands watch by the open doorway. A Ba'al is crouched inside the interrogation room.

Mitchell sits at one side of the table with a folder. Teal'c and Vala sit across from him. Teal'c has his arm on the table, hand upward. Vala is using both hands to try and force it down, to no effect. Teal'c rolls his eyes, looking bored. Landry enters the room. Mitchell stands.
Somebody, give me some good news.
Vala stops her attempts to arm wrestle Teal'c.
Sorry, sir. I still don't have anything useful.
I didn't even make it to first base.
She was just finishing up last time I saw, but I don't think she has anything to report either.
We're running out of time! The NID wants the prisoners, and the President's not going to be able to hold them back forever.
Mitchell notices something on one of the monitors over Landry's shoulder.
Or they're not going to wait.
Agent Barrett. He's talking to one of the Ba'als.
Landry and the others stare at the screen. Barrett and Ba'al stand talking.
I didn't give authorization for that!
While they watch, Ba'al puts his hands up. Barrett punches him. They struggle and Ba'al grabs Barrett's side arm from its shoulder holster.
Ba'al shoots Barrett, then aims for the SF at the door.
Carter walks down a hallway. Behind her, she hears two gunshots. She spins and nods to an SF on guard. Another SF stands nearby.
The SF hands over his radio.
(into radio) This is Colonel Carter requesting backup, Level 16, Corridor B.
Carter presses the alarm button and turns to the SFs.
(to one SF) Come with me. (to other SF) You, cover both.
The SF nods as Carter and the first SF run down the hallway.
In another corridor, a Ba'al swipes a keycard through the slot. It opens.
Mitchell and Landry watch as one Ba'al greets another and hands him a spare weapon. They both leave the interrogation room.
(into phone) This is General Landry. I need a full security lockdown of Levels 15 through 17, now!
The security monitors turn to static.
And there goes the feed. We're blind!
Mitchell, Teal'c and Vala leave the room. Landry looks on with concern.

Carter and the SF cautiously approach the open interrogation room. Weaponless, Carter holds back and signals the SF to take lead. He does a quick sweep and kneels by the downed guard. Carter runs over to Barrett's side. Barrett grimaces in pain. She grabs his hand.
Oh, Sam! He got away. He got my gun!
It's okay. We'll get you out of here.
Carter glances over to the SF. Based on his response, she shakes her head, closing her eyes in regret. She helps Barrett to his feet.
The three walk down the corridor.

They spin to find Ba'al Four with a zat trained on them. Ba'al Eight comes from behind him and fires twice, downing the SF and Carter. Barrett turns to find two more Ba'als at the end of the corridor, also with weapons. One Ba'al fires his zat, and Barrett too falls.
place: SGC CORRIDOR LEVEL 16 AND INTERROGATION ROOM

speech: Landry strides down a hallway. Mitchell, Vala, and Teal'c, all kitted in vests and carrying weapons, follow behind him.
We have emergency forces in position at all access points, sir. All three levels are locked down and secure.
Landry nods to an SF, who opens a door to the team.
place: SGC CORRIDOR, NEAR BILL LEE'S LAB

speech: The group enters Lee's lab. Lee sits by a console. Other scientists work nearby.
What've you got for me, Doctor?
Uh, well...we're thinking our best bet is symbiote poison, introduced in gas form into all three levels.
Vala glances at Teal'c and his pouch.
(continuing) It-it won't harm any of our people, but it will kill any of the Goa'uld who come in contact with it.
Well, it's-it's not that simple. You see, we'll have to use the ventilation system to distribute the gas, and, eh, it's not really designed for that sort of thing.
Lee points to a schematic of the ventilation system.

I-I can, uh, run some simulations and determine the optimum points to seal off the levels and to insert the gas, but even at optimum efficiency, it won't be distributed evenly. There-there's bound to be dead pockets where the gas will take longer before it has any effect.
(starting to talk over him) All-all right, so what you're saying is, depending on location, some of the Ba'als may get advance warning, sir.
(shaking her head) As soon as they realize what's happening, they're going to kill the hostages.
Then we must be prepared to provide a distraction at the moment the gas is released.

Carter awakens to find her hands tied behind her back. Barrett lies next to her. She sits up and notices he and various guards are similarly restrained and unconscious. The door opens and Ba'al Two enters, carrying a rifle.
Get up. We don't have much time.
Carter struggles to rise. Ba'al Two helps her to her feet and leads her out of the room.
Mitchell, Vala and Teal'c move through a corridor, followed by several military forces.
Remember, we can't afford to be seen until Dr. Lee gives us the signal.
No improvising this time. We stick to the plan.
Despite the fact that my improvisations have been extremely useful in the past?
(pointing to access shaft) That's your entry point.
Vala opens the shaft and enters it, a few guards remaining with her. Mitchell and Teal'c continue on with some SFs.
The door opens and Ba'al Two leads Carter in. Several Ba'als surround a computer terminal on a desk.
Ba'al Two releases her restraints and escorts her over to the terminal. She takes a seat by it.
Carter looks at the display requesting an access code.
You're trying to download the list of planets from the Ancient database.
A Ba'al patrols the corridor. Unnoticed, Mitchell and his team stay covered in a side corridor.

Teal'c and his team head down a corridor. Teal'c hears something and orders them to hide in a side passage. Immediately after, Ba'al Six starts down the corridor, rifle at ready. He continues down as Ba'al Five appears behind him.
What are you doing? We need to join the others.
Ba'al Six joins Ba'al Five and they go through the door at the end of the hall. As soon as everything is clear, Teal'c and his team move in the other direction.
You want Merlin's weapon for yourselves.
A weapon capable of destroying not only the Ori, but the Ancients as well. I'd say that's a pretty valuable commodity.
This would be an inappropriate time for heroics, Colonel.
Go ahead and kill me. It's only a matter of time before we regain control of this level. Good luck trying to figure out the code before then.
I would never dream of killing you. But I will kill the other hostages. (to Ba'al Seven) You. start with Agent Barrett.
Ba'al Seven smirks and primes his weapon, heading for the door.
Wait. (She pauses and sighs) I'll do it.
Siler opens the grate and enters the shaft.
(into radio) I'm in position, Doc. Level 14, Section C-9 on the ventilation grid.
Landry and Lee wait in the lab, looking at the schematic.
(into radio) All right, that's our main access point on the North side. Now, the first thing you'll need to do is seal off the vent before the junction.
Why is this taking so long?
You did something to slow the download, didn't you?
I don't know what you're talking about.
(scoffing) It doesn't matter. You can't stop us, anyway. (to other Ba'als) Check the perimeter. They'll be coming soon.
The other Ba'als leave, weapons at ready. Carter bites her lip.
Vala and a group of SFs move stealthily down the hall. Footsteps approach. Vala signals, and they all take cover behind some canisters. Right afterwards, some Ba'als appear alert and ready.
Mitchell and his team are hiding. Mitchell uses his mirror to see Ba'als patrolling everywhere.
(low into radio) Teal'c, Vala, we've got a bit of a dead end here. You got Carter's twenty?
Teal'c and his team are also in hiding.
(into radio) Negative. I am similarly immobilized.
Around the corner, another Ba'al patrols.
We're setting up five separate access points. They all have to be ready to go simultaneously. It's just going to take a minute.
Landry shakes his head and continues pacing. Lee types at his keyboard.
The download is complete. Carter, looking disgusted, slowly picks up the drive, but Ba'al One snatches it from her hands.
It won't do you any good. They'll never let you off this base, even if you kill us all.
Yes, that's what I wanted you to think. Otherwise, you never would've given me the code.
(crouching down) I knew they wouldn't negotiate. Not even for you. Not with something like this at stake.
Ba'al One stands, puts the drive in his pocket, and pulls out a Beretta. Carter looks nervous.
Ba'al One exits, then uses a keycard to lock the door.
Carter approaches the door and tries to open it, then hits and kicks it. She turns away in frustration.
Where the hell is that gas?
(whispering into radio) I don't mean to rush you boys, but we're about to be discovered here.
The guards watch as she breaks cover and fires her zat, downing Ba'al Nine. Ba'al Sixteen and another Ba'al take cover and return fire. The SFs begin to shoot. One SF is downed by a P-90.
Mitchell's team begins exchanging fire with other Ba'als. One SF is downed by a zat.
(through radio) We have gunfire on Level 16.
(into radio) Siler, this is General Landry. Forget about a coordinated attack. Just hit 'em with as much gas as you can, now!
Siler shoves the hose into the ventilation shaft. He then opens the valves on all the gas canisters. Smoke starts pouring into the shaft.

Vala's team and Mitchell's team continue to exchange fire with various Ba'als. Ba'al Eight is downed by a bullet from Mitchell or one of his team. Other Ba'als congregate and retreat. Teal'c and Vala's teams meet up.
We have a man down. Are you all right?
The door to the room bursts open as Mitchell kicks it in. Carter looks up from by the computer to find Mitchell and his team there, weapons ready. Mitchell aims his weapon away from Carter.
We've got 'em on the run. It looks like they're retreating back to one of the isolation rooms.
(worriedly) Wait a minute. All of them together?
Carter races out of the room.
Carter, Mitchell, and his team jog to join Teal'c and Vala's teams exchanging weapons fire with various Ba'als as they head into one of the isolation rooms.
The ventilation shaft starts spewing out the symbiote poison. Two of the Ba'als collapse from its effects. Sam hurries to the isolation room.
Carter looks in from the doorway at the room full of Ba'als.
You're too late. The symbiote poison.
You're the one who's too late.
As Mitchell and guards round the corner, the group of Ba'als are beamed away.
The Ba'als appear in the tel'tak. Ba'al One approaches the Jaffa at the controls of the cargo ship.
(with Goa'uld echo) Get us out of here.
The tel'tak decloaks and jumps into hyperspace.
Teal'c, Carter, Landry, Mitchell, and Vala sit around the table.
How the hell did he do it?
It looks like the locator beacons actually served a dual purpose. In close proximity, they combined to amplify the signal, enough to be picked up through our jamming screen.
That's why he needed us to go and round up all the clones and bring them here. He was playing us from the start.
This was all so that he could get his hands on that list of planets.
He must genuinely believe that Merlin's weapon is hidden on one of them.
Even so, he took a great risk. It was only because Agent Barrett violated protocol that he was afforded the opportunity to escape the interrogation room.
And that was the reason he was able to get all the clones in one place so they could beam out.
So if the whole thing was planned in advance, how did he know what Agent Barrett was going to do?
All of them exchange looks of realization.
Barrett sits at the table, his briefcase beside him. Landry and the team enter.
Agent Barrett, we need to talk.
Did you read the reports on Ba'al's attempts to take control of the Jaffa High Council?
The council members were influenced by some form of mind control.
So, what were you doing in Ba'al's cell?
You had no authorization for that.
You were stonewalling me. I decided to take matters into my own hands.
You took your weapon into the interrogation room.
Yeah. Yeah, I shouldn't have done that. That was a mistake.
See, the Malcolm Barrett I know would never have made that kind of mistake.
Your record indicates your entire career has been strictly by the book. Now, suddenly, out of the blue, you're a "cowboy"?
What are you guys saying? You think that I've been brainwashed.
The technology is readily available to the Goa'uld who infiltrated the Trust. Their loyalty is to Ba'al.
Somebody must have given him the specs to our anti-beaming technology. It's the only way he could've known that the combined signal would be enough to punch through.
Yeah, I agree with that. But it wasn't me.
Ba'al's plan hinged on knowing in advance he'd have the opportunity to get out of that cell. He knew you were coming.
Barrett gathers his papers and stands, picking up his briefcase.
You didn't know you were doing anything wrong.
I gotta go. I'm due back in Washington.
You're not going anywhere. (to guards) Sergeant.
Barrett looks at Landry, then opens his coat wider, allowing one of the guards to remove his gun from its holster. Barrett looks at Carter.
Sam, you know this isn't true.
Carter looks away. Barrett leaves with the guard escort.
Sir, I'm sorry. I should never have given Ba'al that code.
You had no way of knowing. Under the circumstances, you did the right thing.
Landry leaves. Teal'c and Vala follow. Carter sits against the table. Mitchell sits beside her.
So, what do you think? You think Ba'al really has a way of figuring out where that weapon is?
(softly) Hard to say. I mean, Anubis knew the addresses of all those planets, and he never found it. Mind you, there was only one of him.
Carter sniffs in mild laughter and nudges Mitchell with her shoulder.
